name: Learn Unity
tagline: Unity project examples for the book Learn Unity 4 for iOS Game Development
body: This is the GitHub page for the book Learn Unity 4 for iOS Game Development and the accompanying Learn Unity bowling game app. The GitHub projects, built up cumulatively through each chapter to create a bowling game (similar in style to [HyperBowl](http://hyperbowl3d.com/), do not include assets from the Unity Asset Store and Standard Assets that are used in the book, but you can use them a starting point or to save time in constructing the book examples (but taking shortcuts isn't really recommended). The projects are covered under the MIT open source license. # Availability * [Apress alpha ebook](http://www.apress.com/9781430248750) * [Amazon](http://www.amazon.com/Learn-Unity-iOS-Game-Development/dp/1430248750) (print and kindle book) * [Barnes and Noble](http://www.barnesandnoble.com/w/learn-unity-4-for-ios-game-development-philip-chu/1113931582?ean=9781430248750) (print and nook book) # Summary The book and app (see below) demonstrate Unity graphics, audio and physics, scripting in JavaScript (and a little bit of C#), touchscreen and accelerometer input, iAd banner and interstitial ads, Game Center leaderboard and achievements, complete rules for a bowling game, and utilizes free Asset Store packages. The book also covers debugging, profiling and optimization, testing with the Unity Remote and iOS Simulator, build and App Store submission procedures. Most of the chapters cumulatively build a 3D bowling app with the same control style as [HyperBowl](http://hyperbowl3d.com/), but the Angry Bots demo included with Unity is used to introduce Unity features and a simple spinning cube and dancing skeleton scene is also constructed. Technical review was provided by Marc Sh√•rer of [Gayasoft](http://gayasoft.ch). # Chapter Descriptions 1. Downloading and installing Unity, license activation, bug reporting, getting help. 2. Angry Bots demo, built-in and custom layouts, the Scene, Game, Hierarchy, Inspector and Project Views, how to open a project, open a scene and play a scene. 3. Creating a new scene with primitive objects, lighting, skybox, camera control, importing Standard Assets, and making prefabs. 4. Creating scripts, understanding callbacks, editing with MonoDevelop, debugging with MonoDevelop. 5. Creating a dancing skeleton scene by importing a free skeleton package from the Asset Store, selecting and looping a dance animation, importing and looping music, adding a floor, activating dynamic shadows. 6. Starting a new bowling game scene: add a bowling ball, add physics materials and rigidbodies, script a physics-based bowing ball controls. 7. Add bowling pins, a bowling ball game controller, pin collision sounds, ball rolling sound, collision callbacks. 8. Implement complete bowling game rules as a finite state machine, using coroutines. 9. Implement a scoreboard and pause menu using UnityGUI. 10. Build Angry Bots as an iOS app, testing it in the Editor with Unity Remote and on the iOS Simulator in Xcode. 11. Set up provisioning profiles and test devices on the Provisioning Portal, setting up an app on iTunes Connect, build and run Angry Bots for testing and distribution. 12. Back to bowling: adding icons and splash screens, specifying screen orientation, scaling UnityGUI for different screen resolutions. 13. Adding touchscreen controls, detecting shakes with the accelerometer, displaying a video texture with the iOS camera as a webcam. 14. Adding Game Center leaderboards and achievements. 15. Adding banner and interstitial (full-screen) ads with iAd. 16. Running the built-in and Editor-based profiler, optimizing code and assets for speed, size and/or quality. 17. Misc topics: Android, C#, Editor scripting, script execution order, publishing on the Asset Store. Review sites: * [Goodreads](http://www.goodreads.com/book/show/17063557-learn-unity-4-for-ios-game-development) # Asset Store The book utilizes free packages from the Unity Asset Store: * [Eighteen Free Substances](https://www.assetstore.unity3d.com/#/content/1352) from [Allegorithmic](http://allegorithmic.com) * [Free ArtskillZ Texture Pack 01](https://www.assetstore.unity3d.com/#/content/351) from [ArtskillZ](http://artskillz.net) * [Skeletons Pack](https://www.assetstore.unity3d.com/#/content/1818) from [bisaniyehocam](https://www.assetstore.unity3d.com/#/publisher/645) * [General Music Set](https://www.assetstore.unity3d.com/#/content/2589) from [Gianmarco Leone](http://gianmarcoleone.com/) * [Free SFX Package](https://www.assetstore.unity3d.com/#/content/5178) from [Bleep Blop Audio](http://bleepblopaudio.com/) * [Barrel](https://www.assetstore.unity3d.com/#/content/840) from [Universal Image](http://monstertruckherohd.com/) * [iTween](http://itween.pixelplacement.com) from [Pixel Placement](http://pixelplacement.com) # Support Questions can be posted on the [Unity forum](http://forum.unity3d.com/threads/173210-Learn-Unity-for-iOS-Game-Development), any of my Facebook pages ([Technicat](http://facebook.com/technicatllc), [Fugu Games](http://facebook.com/fugugames) or [HyperBowl](http://facebook.com/hyperbowl)) and on [twitter](http://twitter.com/fugugames). # Corrections and Clarifications ## Retail Description * Some retail descriptions list Unity's Mecanim animation system. The book does mention but does not use Mecanim. Instead, a chapter is devoted to a dancing skeleton example using Unity's Legacy animation system and a free skeleton package on the Asset Store. * Some retail descriptions list Unity's support for gyroscope on iOS devices. The book does mention but does not use Unity's gyroscope API (Input.gyroscope). The book does describe how to access the touchscreen (Input.touches), accelerometer (Input.accelerometer), and webcam (WebCamTexture). ## Ebooks ### Apress alpha Hasn't been updated to the final copy. ### Nook URL's display with markup and are not active as links. ### Kindle Figure links don't always work. ## Chapters ### Chapter 1 * page 25: The free version of Unity does now include Unity iOS Basic, which no longer costs $400. * page 27: "The 3D game engines are very complicated" should read "3D game engines are very complicated" ### Chapter 2 * page 33: "go ahead and buildl an OS X app" should read "go ahead and build an OS X app" * a mangled phrase like "function is called a Log.DebugLog". It should be "called the function Debug.Log" # Other Books You may also be interested in Sue Blackman's [Beginning 3D Game Development with Unity](http://forum.unity3d.com/threads/93775-Beginning-3D-Game-Development-with-Unity/page17) (also from Apress), Will Goldstone's [Unity 3.x Game Development Essentials] (http://www.packtpub.com/unity-3-x-game-development-essentials-with-c-and-javascript-will-goldstone/book), and Jeff Murray's [Game Development for iOS with Unity3D] (http://www.crcpress.com/product/isbn/9781439892190). # The App The [HyperBowl](http://hyperbowl3d.com/)-style bowling game developed by following the book, complete with Asset Store assets and Unity Standard Assets, is [on the App Store](https://itunes.apple.com/app/learn-unity/id634845779 Learn Unity app). There is also an Android version [on Google Play](https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.technicat.HyperBowlComplete) and the [Amazon appstore](http://www.amazon.com/Technicat-LLC-Learn-Unity/dp/B00DHYHKJU/ref=sr_1_14?s=mobile-apps&ie=UTF8&qid=1371837470&sr=1-14).
